Great start to the week for the AI Utility trade heading into $NVDA earnings. 

$NBIS, $IREN, $CIFR

$NET is acquiring AI platform Replicate to pull more than 50K AI models directly into Workers. 

This is the right move because the next phase of AI is all about running models effortlessly at global scale without any GPU babysitting.

$AMZN & $F are teaming up to sell certified used Ford vehicles on Amazon.

Ford now joins Hyundai as another major automaker bringing its cars onto the platform.

$BMNR now owns 2.9% of all Ethereum.

They hold ~3.6M $ETH in treasury & keep increasing their share of the network every week.

$AMZN launches a six-part US dollar high-grade bond offering to raise $12B. 

They are tapping the credit markets  to lock in long-dated funding for data centers, logistics expansion & ongoing AI infra.

$HIMS AUTHORIZES $250M SHARE REPURCHASE PROGRAM

CEO Andrew Dudum says the buyback reflects their view that the stock is undervalued and that the company‚Äôs balance sheet gives them the flexibility to capture that mispricing for shareholders.
$ONDS secured an $8.2M order from a major European security agency to deploy Iron Drone Raider systems at one of Europe‚Äôs largest airports
Anthropic‚Äôs CEO says AI is moving fast enough that unemployment could drift toward 10-20% within a few years  üò≥

$NVDA CEO Jensen Huang is saying there‚Äôs no bubble because AI manufactures intelligence in real time which means every query consumes fresh compute & forces the system to scale its GPU base as usage grows. 

That is why demand for GPUs & power keeps accelerating & why this looks like a genuine industrial build-out rather than a bubble.

Jeff Bezos is stepping back into a formal CEO role to co-lead Project Prometheus, an AI startup targeting engineering & manufacturing across compute, autos & space.

It‚Äôs already raised $6.2B & hired nearly 100 people from $META, OpenAI & DeepMind.

$AMZN just rolled out Ads Agent, an AI system that handles targeting, budget allocation & even SQL-level analytics for you.

It lowers the barrier for smaller advertisers and makes Amazon‚Äôs ad engine even stickier as spend consolidates onto the platform.
Absolutely wild that $AAPL has added roughly $30M of market cap every single hour since Tim Cook took over  üò≥

THE SUPER BOWL OF EARNINGS IS NEXT WEEK

The counterargument is that recent studies suggest AI could eliminate up to 50% of all entry-level white-collar jobs within the next five years, translating to an estimated impact of up to 50 million jobs in the U.S. (link)

In other words, fully one-third of the total workforce (160 million) will be replaced by an electric bill and a monthly subscription to run an LLM to do these jobs. This would skyrocket profit margins and earnings, justifying paying such high valuations.

If this actually happens, and it happens with consequence (unemploying 50 million people in the next five years MIGHT have some consequences), then paying these valuations would truly be "different this time."

I'll go with valuations are too high and the market is determined to disappoint. But, again, it is not a timing tool. It could perform well for another year or so before that disappointment sets in. Or, the high was two weeks ago.

Either way, the market has to reconcile paying such high valuations.

research.aimultiple.com/ai-j‚Ä¶

1/4

I assume Marks is referring to the 1-year forward P/E ratio for the S&P 500, the standard Wall Street valuation metric (which is closer to 25 now, but was 23 a few weeks ago).

Here is a long-term proxy for that ... the Shiller Cyclically Adjusted Price/Earnings (CAPE) ratio back to 1881. It is a 10-year average of P/E/ ratios.

At 40, it is one of the highest readings ever, even higher than 1929.

The truth this chart exposes is that the AI revolution is now a web of financial commitments, hardware dependencies & strategic overlap so intertwined that the line between competition & collaboration barely exists. 

Every line on that chart reflects a feedback loop of capital & dependency because OpenAI relies on $NVDA for hardware, $MSFT for cloud infra & $ORCL for compute & each of those companies in turn depends on OpenAI‚Äôs continued momentum to justify their own CapEx acceleration.

None of this signals that the AI trade is dead but my takeaway is that the straight-line optimism that defined the first couple years after ChatGPT‚Äôs release is giving way to a more sober phase where fundamentals, capacity planning & capital efficiency matter again & that shift is healthy for the entire cycle.

I believe what I believe.

Japan will fucking panic, and I‚Äôm going to annoy the fuck out of all of you when it does.

You will soon understand this.
I‚Äôll be right.

10/10
L-Carnitine won‚Äôt replace discipline‚Äîbut it will amplify it. More fat burned. Better recovery. Easier fasts. Whether you‚Äôre cutting, recomposing, or just want smarter fuel use, it earns its place in your stack. Stay sharp. Stay lean. Few.

7/10
When fasting, energy dips and hunger spikes are common. L-Carnitine helps mitigate both. It supports energy production by unlocking fat stores, keeping you sharper and more stable when you‚Äôre running on empty.

6/10
Body comp matters. L-Carnitine can help reduce fat mass without reducing muscle. In some cases, it may even help build or preserve lean mass. You stay strong while getting leaner. That‚Äôs what true recomposition looks like.

5/10
On average, people taking L-Carnitine in trials lost ~1‚Äì2 kg more fat than controls. It‚Äôs not magic, but it moves the needle. Fat loss comes primarily from diet + training‚Äîbut this gives you a metabolic edge.

4/10
Studies show L-Carnitine helps increase fat burning during workouts, may reduce fatigue, and improve endurance. The longer your body runs on fat, the less it dips into glycogen or breaks down muscle. That‚Äôs key for body composition.

3/10
Why should you care? Because more L-Carnitine = better fat oxidation. That means your body gets more efficient at using fat for energy‚Äîespecially helpful when fasting or doing endurance training.

2/10
L-Carnitine is a compound made from amino acids, found mostly in red meat. It plays a key role in moving fatty acids into your cells‚Äô mitochondria, where they‚Äôre burned for energy. Think of it as a fat shuttle delivering fuel to your engine.
